item.title: Getting Familiar with the Course
item.description:
• Nothing!

Nothing!

There are no examples this week. Go do something!

item.title: Covering the Population and Selecting Who to Survey
item.description:
• Javascript in Qualtrics: Textbox Width

Javascript in Qualtrics: Textbox Width

Synopsis

Qualtrics does not provide a default option to expand or contract the width of the text box. In this walkthrough, you’ll figure out how to use the Javascript engine to rule over Qualtrics!

What you need

Here is a snippet1. You’ll need it for the walkthrough.

Try it out

Try using your initial surveys in Qualtrics to test out how to expand the open text boxes.

Walkthrough

Note: If the link for Atom is not working, please use this link.

  1. Depending on your settings, you may have to right click to download the file.↩︎

item.title: How to Write Open- and Closed-Ended Questions
item.description:
• Javascript in Qualtrics: The Plug

Javascript in Qualtrics: The Plug

Synopsis

Sometimes Qualtrics likes to include things you don’t want. In this walkthrough, you’ll figure out how to use the Javascript engine to get rid of some free advertisement that the service plugs into your survey.

What you need

Here is a snippet1. You’ll need it for the walkthrough.

Walkthrough

item.title: Aural Versus Visual Design of Questions and Questionnaires
item.description:
• Using the Qualtrics API

Using the Qualtrics API

Synopsis

Using the typical approach of logging into Qualtrics, clicking through menu items and then downloading a data set is cumbersome. Moreover the output given by Qualtrics is rarely formatted in user friendly way. In this walkthrough, you’ll figure out how to use the R to access the Qualtrics API. Once you see how easy it is to pull data directly from the source, you may never go back!

What you need

  • The Qualtrics_API.R script1.
  • An open text file to copy and keep ID numbers securely.

Walkthrough: Part I - Gathering IDs

Walkthrough: Part II - Using R to Access Qualtrics

Links

  • Qualtrics support.

  1. You may have to right click and download it depending on your browser settings.↩︎

item.title: Ordering Questions and Testing for Question Order Effects
item.description:
• Visual Clues

Visual Clues

Synopsis

Item development for any instrument is not an easy task. Furthermore you rarely have the chance of amending a question on surveys in particular after distribution so they require that items be perfect. While pilot testing certainly helps with this process, using certain formatting techniques can yield gains in responses.

What you need1

Please download the following files and save them in a single folder

  • likert_colorpalettes_functions.R script.
  • likert_colorpalettes.R script.
  • text_box_size text file.
  • vertical_mc_spacing text file.

Walkthrough: Part I - Spacing

Walkthrough: Part II - Colors

Links

  • Color Hex
  • uiGradients
  • EDP 693 Resources page for Design

  1. You may have to right click and download it depending on your browser settings.↩︎

item.title: Ordering Questions and Testing for Question Order Effects
item.description:
• Visual Clues

Visual Clues

Synopsis

The choices given in Qualtrics can seem daunting in one instance but limited in another. In fact its not a matter of having too many choices, rather in identifying which components within the software will yield the greatest return on response rates. These little short walkthroughs will help you to locate specific functions that go beyond the design aspect into functionality.

What you need1

Please download the following files and unzip them for reference

  • solicitations.zip text file.

Walkthroughs

Posting by Wednesday

  1. You may have to right click and download it depending on your browser settings.↩︎

item.title: Getting to Know the Complex Sample Design
item.description:
• Administering Your Survey
  • An Overlooked Yet Extremely Important Option

Administering Your Survey

Synopsis

The choices given in Qualtrics can seem daunting in one instance but limited in another. Even when intending to administer a final survey, the options can be overwhelming. This week we look less at tweaking the survey platform to learn more about the delivery process.

Read

Familiarize yourself with the Qualtrics Distributions options.

What you need1

Please download the following example files and unzip them. They are optional templates for the solicitations and gratitude sections outlined below.

  • solicitations.zip text file.

Planning

The typical open period of a survey lasts two weeks with each of the following processes automated:

  • Opening day/time: 8am on a Tuesday. If you have respondents scattered across time zones, then this should align with the latest 8am. For example, a survey initiated from the Central time zone across the US would technically begin at 7am CST to account for the Eastern Time Zone.
  • Initial solicitation: Sent on the same Tuesday within 15-30 minutes of the opening time. This is purely intended to give you a cushion for last last minute fixes and changes. Those unfamiliar with Qualtrics will benefit from having the maximum of extra time simply due to the complexity associated with the software.2
  • Opening day/time: 11:59pm on the second Tuesday. Again, if you have respondents scattered across time zones, then this should align with the earliest 8am. For example, a survey initiated from the Central time zone across the US would technically end at 8am HAST to account for the Hawaii-Aleutian Standard Time Zone.

The process below is recommended and tends to walk the line between a lack of and too many reminders. However please use your best judgment.

Days Description Reasoning
-7 to -3 Typically administered three to seven days prior to the initial solicitation, groups that may not be aware of a forthcoming survey are sent a priori information. Suprising potential respondents can reduce response rates. If you feel that members of your sample could benefit from a heads up, then please generate a simple one paragraph description informing them of (1) the upcoming online opportunity, (2) the purpose of the survey, and (3) when they will be recieving it.
1 Initial solicitation adminsitered. Respondents tend to avoid optional tasks on Mondays and are traditionally less likely to participate after noon on Wednesdays. This leaves only Tuesday as the optial day per week to send a survey.
7 First follow-up reminder administered A majority of your respondents will typically participate within the first six days. Providing a reminder on the seventh day often yields an additional responses from those who initially wanted to participate, but simply forgot.
10 Second follow-up reminder administered Known as the small bump, this follow up solicitation is primarily intended for those individuals who may be undecided about participating. You may or may not observe any additional responses and even if you do, they will likely be minimal.
14 Final follow-up reminder administered Assuming a closing time of 11:59PM, this final notice is administered at the earliest 8am to allow for responses from those in your sample who tend to complete tasks at the last minute. You may or may not observe any additional responses and the frequency is often dependent on the characteristics of your sampling frame.
+1 to +3 Typically administered one to three days after the closing of a survey, those who participated are sent a letter of gratitude. In most cases respondents are participating without any amenities - ergo they are doing you a favor. Even if you never intend to survey any of these indivdiuals again, ending a data collection period with a simple gratitude can and often does have lasting ramifications. You simply never know when individuals in your sample could be helpful in the future. The term never burn your bridges is synonymous with this task.

An Overlooked Yet Extremely Important Option

Please make sure that you also look over the Survey Options tab before distribution! It is considered to be the heart of your instrument that allows different parts of Qualtrics to interact with each other.

  1. You may have to right click and download it depending on your browser settings.↩︎

  2. Remember once your survey has populated, that’s it! Tweaking it afterwards can lead to measurement errors or even a collapse of instrumentation. If you absolutely must amend an item and need advice, please contact me.↩︎
